result.execSummary:
The defendant Dennis M. Kaufman was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manufacture/Deliver THC (<=200g) [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(h)1.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Paid.  Bond applied.  $25 drug test fee also taken from bond.  Balance to be returned to poster.

The Defendant is to complete AODA assessment and comply with any treatment recommended.  The Defendant is to undergo any counseling the agent finds appropriate and must comply with any recommended treatment/assessment/counseling.  Defendant may not withdraw from any ordered program without permission of the agent and/or provider.  The Defendant is to obtain and maintain full time employment and/or educational programming of at least 40 hours per week from one job or multiple jobs.  The Defendant is to have no contact with known drug dealers or users.  The Defendant is to maintain absolute sobriety - no alcohol or drugs unless prescribed by a physician.  Defendant is subject to random drug/UA/breath testing.  The Defendant is not to go into any bars, taverns or businesses where the primary purpose is to sell alcohol.  The Defendant is to provide a biological specimen for DNA analysis.

Probation review hearing set for 4/22/16 @ 11:00.

timeConds.notes:
Imposed - 2 months.  If today's drug test is clean, imposed time is with work release.  If the test is dirty, imposed time to be done in lock up.  To begin sentence immediately.
Stayed - 4 months.
Credit is for revocation purposes.
To be completed within first year of probation.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea
